name: New 'Jewish campus' opens in Berlin

extract: An exhibition in Frankfurt looks into the history of plastic in the arts, from avant-garde and Bauhaus experiments to futuristic space-age and trash works.
name: 'Plastic World': Art for the throwaway society

extract: The accident occurred at a camp for fathers and children in the northern state of Lower Saxony. A fire brigade spokesperson said a group had been riding in a box carried by the excavator "for fun."
name: Germany: Excavator accident leaves 2 dead, several injured

extract: Without captain Alex Popp and five Bayern Munich players, Germany failed to impress in their 2-1 win over Vietnam. But the match was more about fine-tuning for the World Cup as this team embraces its favorites tag.
name: Germany fail to flatter vs. Vietnam as 2023 World Cup looms

extract: A summit on global finance has brought together world leaders, international institutions and NGOs in Paris. It could be the beginning of a policy shift in international finance.

extract: A new report details how the takeovers of Premier League football clubs Manchester City and Newcastle United have been facilitated by economic austerity, supported by local politicians and not scrutinized by local media.
name: Sportswashing: Manchester, Newcastle 'easy' targets — report

extract: After the Soviet Union cut supply lines to West Berlin in 1948, Western Allies launched a historic rescue effort: an airlift for more than 2 million residents. Seventy-five years on Germany is commemorating the blockade.
name: Berlin Airlift 75 years on: When 'enemies became friends'

extract: The DFB said it plans to press charges after players reported receiving racist abuse on social media during an under-21 game. "You disgust us. You are not true fans," the federation responded.
name: German football federation decries online racist abuse

extract: The Titan submersible is believed to have imploded. Experts think the materials used to construct the vessel could have cracked under deep-sea pressure.
name: What caused the implosion of the Titan sub?

extract: A new study projects that global diabetes cases will rise from 529 million to 1.3 billion by 2050. What's behind the rise? And how can it be stopped?
name: Diabetes cases predicted to rise to 1.3 billion by 2050

extract: The German parliament has passed legislation to open up new opportunities for job seekers from countries outside the EU and for many refugees who are already in the country. Conservative lawmakers are up in arms.

extract: Germany has 2 million jobs to fill. Now it is reforming its immigration laws to offer streamlined visa processes and new opportunities for qualified foreign workers.

extract: Beijing is portraying Chinese Premier Li Qiang's business-oriented visit to Germany as a diplomatic success, but experts say its impact on reducing long-running tensions will be limited.

extract: Even if it is found, rescue teams would have to reach it with equipment and bring it to the surface, assuming it is still intact.

extract: German writer Erich Maria Remarque, whose landmark anti-war novel was adapted into an Oscar-winning film, was born 125 years ago.
name: Erich Maria Remarque: The legacy of 'All Quiet on the Western Front'

extract: Latin America's biggest eucalyptus pulp producer, Suzano, attracts billions in green bonds despite accusations it harms forests and local communities. DW investigates the controversies surrounding Suzano.
name: Greenwashing concerns surround Brazil's 'sustainable' paper company

extract: The online giant has been accused of tricking customers into joining its Prime service, "trapping" them in automatically renewing subscriptions. Such memberships are a main profit driver for the retail behemoth.

extract: Cervical cancer is almost always caused by a HPV infection. A new affordable HPV test could help countries screen patients, making it a critical step towards eradicating cervical cancer.

extract: Italian photographer Gabriele Galimberti traveled around the globe to photograph children and their favorite toys: The contrasts in their belongings is worth 1,000 words.

extract: Foreign debt cripples countries vulnerable to extreme weather events, hindering climate change resilience. Reforming financial systems could help them combat climate change.

extract: June 21 is International Day of Yoga. Sangeeta Lerner aims to draw awareness to yoga’s spiritual roots, as a way of life rather than a sport, criticizing the ancient practice's commercialization.

extract: China clearly doesn’t want to be drawn any deeper than it has to into the diplomatic and rhetorical war over Ukraine, which may partly explain its move to aid the US and EU in tightening the sanctions on Russia.

extract: Victor Wembanyama is considered basketball's new Wunderkind, and the hype surrounding the 19-year-old Frenchman is already immense. He's expected to join the San Antonio Spurs in the NBA.

extract: Environmental concerns are one of several factors driving up airfares. DW explores what's behind the price hikes.

extract: Hansi Flick’s Germany are in a rut ahead of EURO 2024. Defeat to Colombia marks not only the end of the season, but also the culmination of a terrible run of form that Leon Goretzka has labeled "dramatic."

extract: Mental health remains a big issue in Ghana. But some Ghanaian female footballers are shattering the stigma of silence as they look to change the narrative around the issue.

extract: Following his reelection, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has signaled a policy shift, possibly moving away from keeping interest rates low. The crisis-ridden country may be headed for a turnaround.

extract: While the high seas make up over 60% of the world's oceans, they have long drawn less attention than coastal waters. A UN treaty aims to change that by attempting to ensure the sustainable use of ocean biodiversity.

extract: Three hundred years ago, Johann Sebastian Bach came to Leipzig as cantor. This was celebrated extensively at the Bachfest. His works continue to shape the music world today.

extract: As big energy companies make record profits and expand production of climate-wrecking fossil fuels, activists are appealing directly to shareholders to demand rapid emission cuts.

extract: The celebrated British-American author of "Midnight's Children" and "The Satanic Verses" has been recognized with the Peace Prize of the German Book Trade.

extract: Kuwait, the first Arab Asian nation at the World Cup, has faded from its glory days. Meanwhile, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE invest heavily in international sports, leaving the former football powerhouse behind.

extract: Germany will submit its application for the 19th-century iconic castle to be its next World Heritage site, after 56% of residents in the surrounding city voted to do so.

extract: One of the most highly regarded German talents of recent decades, Kai Havertz has had ups and downs since his big move to Chelsea. His time in west London seems to be over, and his next step looks a critical one
name: Kai Havertz at crossroads amid Arsenal, Bayern Munich links

extract: The latest El Nino climate phenomenon has arrived, threatening floods in some areas of the world and droughts in others. Previous disruptive weather patterns cost the global economy trillions and stoked inflation.

extract: Mäder's Bahrain Victorious and two additional teams said they wanted to respect their members' wishes and well-being by leaving the Tour de Suisse. The race is scheduled to carry on, despite Mäder's death.

extract: Scientists have dubbed the dinosaur Gonkoken nanoi, which means "similar to a wild duck or a swan" in the Tehuelche language.

extract: King Charles III marks his official birthday celebrations by riding horseback in a military parade — the first time a monarch has done this in almost 40 years. But what is 'Trooping the Color'?

extract: Maybe you have one of the telltale signs or maybe you’re frantic after a positive test at the doctor’s office. HPV can be scary, but the stigma is usually worse than the virus itself.
name: I have HPV. What should I do?

extract: Young female fans of K-pop bands are often brushed off as hysterical. But that's sexist, says a researcher, arguing excitement about a soccer game is no different.

extract: After an EU court ruling, Polish banks are facing a $25 billion hit in the ongoing Swiss franc mortgage case. What does it mean for banks, borrowers and the financial sector?

extract: The European Central Bank announced a quarter-point interest rate hike as inflation remains too high. The move comes after the US Fed left rates unchanged.

extract: The US Federal Reserve has held interest rates steady, as previously hinted, after 10 consecutive hikes. But Jerome Powell also indicated that further increases were possible this year.

extract: German stocks have rallied to a new record amid expectations that US interest rate rises are about to plateau.

extract: Many tourists make voluntary carbon offsetting payments to reduce their greenhouse gas footprint. The practice, however, is increasingly controversial.

extract: The latest policy rift within Germany's three-party coalition government appears to have been resolved with a compromise deal. This time it was over planned changes to laws on heating.

extract: Every vaccination, including the COVID-19 shot, can cause side effects like fatigue and muscle pain. But it is difficult to diagnose so-called post-vaccination syndrome. What do we know about vaccine damage?

extract: Why the German state pays millions of euros to the Christian churches each year, and how shedding the financial burden could cost it dearly.

extract: With an El Nino weather cycle set to amplify temperature extremes, TV meteorologists have a vital role in communicating the added impact of climate change.

extract: Intense wildfires have destroyed forests and homes across Canada and forced thousands to evacuate. Online, the fires' cause — and the role of climate change — has sparked rumors and misinformation. A look at the facts.

extract: A blood test for more than 50 types of cancer showed promise when it came to detecting the disease in patients with symptoms.

extract: The biggest European banking deal in 15 years has been finalized. The merger with UBS puts an end to Credit Suisse's 167-year history.
name: Switzerland: UBS completes Credit Suisse takeover

extract: Some fear automated stock trading done by computers will fall victim to fake images generated with artificial intelligence (AI). But experts say algorithmic trading could actually be the key to market stability.
name: AI: Are stock markets ready for it?

extract: Germany found that 740 people were involved in 580 different offenses committed by the climate activist group Last Generation.
name: Germany records 580 offenses committed by climate activist group

extract: Despite being legalized in a number of countries worldwide, cannabis is still shrouded in misinformation. In this DW fact check, we examine four of the biggest myths surrounding the drug.
name: Fact check: How dangerous is cannabis, really?

extract: Experts say Ukraine's biggest nuclear power plant is stable after the Nova Kakhova dam explosion and under no risk in the short term.

extract: Several trials have found that a shorter workweek can boost worker productivity and reduce burnout. Advocates argue it could also have benefits for the environment.

extract: A drop in commodity prices for things like wheat and energy has brought the specter of recession closer, not long after inflationary fears dominated the picture. The global economy seems to be in a state of confusion.

extract: Human-induced warming was rising at an "unprecedented" rate, new research has again shown. Meanwhile, a look at various countries' commitment to their net-zero plans showed most polluters were lagging behind.

extract: Nigeria's president has scrapped fuel subsidies, saying the billions of dollars will now go toward improving the country's infrastructure. But experts say the oil industry has bigger problems.

extract: Researchers are trying to figure out why groups of orcas regularly damage boats in the Strait of Gibraltar — sometimes even sinking them. Many believe the behavior isn’t aggression, but teenage antics.

extract: The destruction of a major dam in Ukraine is catastrophic for the environment and will mean that parts of nature are 'lost forever,' says Ukraine environment minister Ruslan Strilets.

extract: Infrequent periods and unexplained weight gain? It could be polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) — the most common hormonal disorder in women of childbearing age. Despite its high prevalence, many have never heard of it.

extract: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in southern Ukraine is Europe's largest nuclear facility. It's also central to Russia's war. Experts say a meltdown would spell disaster.
